importance: This paper is crucial for researchers in reinforcement learning and Monte Carlo Tree Search (MCTS).  It **bridges the gap between distributional reinforcement learning and MCTS**, offering a novel approach to handle uncertainty in stochastic environments. The provided theoretical guarantees and empirical results demonstrate the efficacy of the proposed methods, opening up **new avenues for improving the performance of MCTS in challenging real-world scenarios**.
summary: Boosting MCTS performance in stochastic environments, this paper introduces CATS and PATS, novel algorithms using distributional RL and Thompson Sampling, achieving superior results with theoretical guarantees.
takeaways: CATS and PATS, two novel algorithms combining distributional reinforcement learning and Thompson Sampling for MCTS, are introduced.
Theoretical analysis proves the algorithms achieve a simple regret of order O(n⁻¹), improving upon the state-of-the-art.
Empirical evidence demonstrates the efficacy of the proposed approach in both stochastic and deterministic environments.
tldr:
Traditional Monte Carlo Tree Search (MCTS) struggles with highly stochastic environments, leading to suboptimal decision-making.  Distributional Reinforcement Learning (RL), which models value functions as distributions rather than single values, shows promise but hasn't been fully integrated into MCTS.  This is a significant limitation because many real-world problems are inherently stochastic.
This paper introduces two novel algorithms, CATS and PATS, which address this gap.  **CATS and PATS leverage distributional RL to model uncertainty within MCTS**, using categorical and particle-based distributions respectively. They also incorporate Thompson Sampling for action selection, improving exploration and exploitation. The paper offers theoretical guarantees on the algorithms' performance and provides empirical evidence supporting their effectiveness across various stochastic and deterministic environments.
